qas.question: What is the benefit to chickens of being in a free-range farming location?

answers.text: the birds have access to natural conditions and can exhibit their normal behaviours

qas.question: What is yarding in relation to the pultry industry?

answers.text: birds have access to a fenced yard and poultry house at a higher stocking rate

qas.question: What is the most intensive type of enclosure system used in the poultry business?

answers.text: battery cages, often set in multiple tiers

qas.question: How are eggs collected in teh battery cage system?

answers.text: The eggs are laid on the floor of the cage and roll into troughs outside for ease of collection

plausible_answers.text: the birds have access to natural conditions and can exhibit their normal behaviours

qas.question: What is the benefit to chickens of being in a caged location?

plausible_answers.text: the birds have access to a fenced yard and poultry house at a higher stocking rate

qas.question: What is yarding in relation to the pottery industry?

plausible_answers.text: battery cages, often set in multiple tiers

qas.question: What is the only type of enclosure system used in the poultry business?

plausible_answers.text: The eggs are laid on the floor of the cage and roll into troughs outside for ease of collection

qas.question: How are eggs destroyed in the battery cage system?
When did battery cages become the only way to house hens?

context: In free-range husbandry, the birds can roam freely outdoors for at least part of the day. Often, this is in large enclosures, but <a0_0><b4_0>the birds have access to natural conditions and can exhibit their normal behaviours<b4_0/><a0_0/>. A more intensive system is yarding, in which <b5_0>the <a1_0>birds have access to a fenced yard and poultry house at a higher stocking rate<b5_0/><a1_0/>. Poultry can also be kept in a barn system, with no access to the open air, but with the ability to move around freely inside the building. The most intensive system for egg-laying chickens is <a2_0><b6_0>battery cages, often set in multiple tiers<b6_0/><a2_0/>. In these, several birds share a small cage which restricts their ability to move around and behave in a normal manner. <a3_0><b7_0>The eggs are laid on the floor of the cage and roll into troughs outside for ease of collection<b7_0/><a3_0/>. Battery cages for hens have been illegal in the EU since <b8_0>January 1, 2012<b8_0/>.
